etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Andrew Borde (c1490–1549), physician and author. Originally irregularly from classical Latin stupendus, after adjectives in -ious; compare tremendious, variant of tremendous

definitions: Amazing, extremely impressive; very large or great; extraordinarily good or pleasing.

notes.text: More common than stupendous until the early 18th century. Compare also stupenduous.
